themes.title: Polychrome Porcelain: Wucai and Its Significance
points: Introduce Wucai (â€˜five-colour') porcelains as a vibrant polychrome style widely produced during the late Ming and Qing dynasties.
Explain how the use of multiple colors reflects advancements in ceramic techniques and the Ming dynasty's artistic innovation.
Discuss the cultural symbolism of colors in Ming porcelain, such as red for prosperity and green for vitality, connecting to students' interest in symbolism.

themes.title: Imperial Marks and Courtly Connections
points: Highlight the significance of imperial marks on Ming porcelain, indicating pieces made for the court and related institutions.
Explain how these marks reflect the centralized power and prestige of the Ming dynasty, tying into the students' World History curriculum.
Encourage students to imagine the role of art in representing authority and cultural identity during this period.

themes.title: Global Influence: Ming Porcelain in Europe
points: Discuss how early Ming dynasty blue-and-white porcelain reached the Ducal court of the Medicis in Florence, showcasing China's global influence.
Explain how the Medicis valued these pieces as symbols of wealth and sophistication, linking to the students' interest in symbolism.
Ask students to consider how trade and cultural exchange shaped perceptions of Chinese art in Europe.

themes.title: Blue-and-White Porcelain: A Ming Legacy
points: Explain the enduring popularity of blue-and-white porcelain during the Ming period, emphasizing its aesthetic appeal and technical mastery.
Discuss the symbolism of blue-and-white designs, such as motifs of dragons (power) and lotus flowers (purity), connecting to students' interest in religious and symbolic themes.
Encourage students to observe specific patterns on exhibit pieces and think about their meanings in the Ming cultural context.
